title: 110_s1812
content: The Act may be cited as the "Mentoring America's Children Act of 2007" and includes amendments to mentoring programs. The "Mentoring America's Children Act of 2007" includes amendments to improve outcomes for children by enhancing school connectedness, reducing absenteeism, and boosting academic performance, as well as fostering character education. The "Mentoring America's Children Act of 2007" includes amendments to enhance school connectedness, reduce absenteeism, boost academic performance, and foster character education. Amendments include expanding eligibility criteria for positive role models, forming partnerships between educational agencies and organizations, and emphasizing responsibility and success in grant programs. The "Mentoring America's Children Act of 2007" includes amendments to address issues faced by children in different areas, such as high crime rates, gang involvement, and drug use. It encourages goal-setting, planning for the future, and discourages gang involvement. The "Mentoring America's Children Act of 2007" includes amendments requiring eligible entities to provide information on staffing and monitoring plans for mentor/mentee matches, as well as sustainability plans to meet funding match requirements. The "Mentoring America's Children Act of 2007" mandates that grant recipients must match a certain percentage of the funding awarded each year, with increasing requirements over a three-year period. The "Mentoring America's Children Act of 2007" requires grant recipients to match a percentage of funding awarded each year, with increasing requirements over three years. The Act aims to support children in troubled environments, schools with violence, and foster children in urban, suburban, and rural areas through mentoring programs. The "Mentoring America's Children Act of 2007" requires grant recipients to match a percentage of funding awarded each year, with increasing requirements over three years. Subsequent grants are awarded based on satisfactory performance in program design and serving children, exclusively supporting expanded services to new areas or populations, and demonstrating a 50 percent match. The "Mentoring America's Children Act of 2007" mandates a 50 percent match to Federal funds for all 3 years of the new grant. The Secretary may have a policy prohibiting an entity from having 2 grants simultaneously, except when the periods overlap by 3 months or less. Additionally, Section 4130 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to ensure quality grants and support for grantees. The Secretary will provide training, track mentoring practices, and submit annual reports for grant recipients. Research on school-based mentoring will be conducted to ensure access to current information. To ensure grant recipients have access to current research-based knowledge on effective mentoring programs, the Secretary will consult with leading mentoring organizations and researchers to determine research priorities and appropriate design for school-based mentoring. This includes identifying ideal school environments and techniques for matching children with specific characteristics. The Secretary will issue grants or contracts to research entities to study effective mentoring models for school-based mentoring, focusing on matching children with specific characteristics and refining best practices for optimal outcomes. The Secretary will issue grants or contracts only if the appropriated amount exceeds $50,000,000 for each fiscal year. Authorization of appropriations is set at $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2008 and may vary for succeeding years. The Secretary can allocate up to 5% of funds for grantee support and up to 10% for research. Mentoring for minority programs is included in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include mentoring programs in various sections, such as Section 7205(a)(3) and Section 7304(a)(2)(P). Additionally, transition services under Section 1418(a)(2)(C) are also impacted. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include youth mentoring programs in transition services and national safe and drug-free schools programs. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include school and community-based mentoring programs.
